metadata.case_name: City Municipality v. State of Bombay

facts.text: The appellant is a City Municipality within the meaning of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 and is governed by that Act.
Appellant Municipality passed a resolution under s. 60 selecting octroi tax of -/4/- annas per Bengali maund on milk brought within octroi limits for consumption, use or sale therein.
Government of Bombay gave sanction to the rule under s. 61 on November 29, 1954.
Appellant Municipality published the rule and sanction as required by s. 62; tax imposed with effect from January 1, 1955.
Government of Bombay passed order on April 4, 1955 directing that the octroi tax shall not be leviable by the appellant Municipality.

Appellant Municipality filed petition under Art. 226 in Bombay High Court challenging validity of the order; dismissed by judgment and order dated July 19, 1955 in Special Civil Application No. 976 of 1955.
Procedure prescribed in ss. 59-62 complied with.
Government had earlier requested appellant to drop the tax on ground, inter alia, that milk was purchased for Government which was not liable to be taxed by Municipality.
Government prohibited all Municipalities from levying octroi tax on milk.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Government order dated April 4, 1955 prohibiting levy of octroi tax on milk is competent under s. 59 of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901, even after sanction under s. 61.
Whether the order is discriminatory under Art. 14.
Whether the order was made mala fide.

petitioner_arguments.text: General or special orders in s. 59 are orders in existence before rule prescribing tax was framed; once rule framed and sanctioned, Government has no power to control imposition by order under s. 59.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 s. 59; ss. 60-62

petitioner_arguments.text: Word 'impose' in s. 59 means acquisition of power to tax by following procedure in ss. 60-62.
General or special orders refer to orders under s. 73, but present order not under s. 73 which only suspends till objections removed.
Order discriminatory as no other Municipality prohibited from collecting similar tax.
Order mala fide to benefit respondent No. 2, a cooperative union dealing in milk.

respondent_arguments.text: Order competent as authorised by s. 59, subject to which tax can be imposed by Municipality.
Municipality being local authority is State, not entitled to Art. 14; no discrimination as all Municipalities prohibited from levying octroi on milk.

court_reasoning.text: Municipality's power to tax arises only under s. 59, subject to general or special orders of Government; 'impose' means actual levy after rules sanctioned, not acquisition of power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imposition after making rule is subject to Government's orders; s. 61 sanction different from s. 59 orders.

court_reasoning.text: S. 59(1)(a) makes imposition after s. 60 compliance; s. 62 imposes from date specified by Municipality, distinguishing rule-making from actual levy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Impose' in s. 59 construed as in s. 62, meaning actual levy subject to orders.

court_reasoning.text: S. 73 not relevant; does not confine s. 59 orders to suspensions.
No discrimination; Government prohibited all Municipalities from levying octroi on milk; all stand on same footing.
No mala fides; earlier request on valid grounds even if untenable; similar orders to all Municipalities; bare allegation re respondent No. 2 unsupported.
Ayyangar J.: Power under s. 59 opening words continuing; not exhausted after initial imposition; imposition is continuing power; s. 73 limited; scheme of Act gives Govt wide control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No exhaustion; Govt can prohibit continued imposition in public interest.

holdings.text: Government competent under s. 59 to issue order prohibiting levy of octroi tax on milk even after sanction under s. 61.
Order not discriminatory; no mala fides.
Order dated April 4, 1955 perfectly legitimate and upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs imposition of octroi tax by Municipality; s. 59 subjects imposition to Govt orders; ss. 60-62 procedure; Govt power to control/prohibit levy.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 226 for High Court petition; Art. 14 for discrimination challenge.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Bombay High Court dismissal of Art. 226 petition challenging Govt order prohibiting octroi on milk dismissed; order upheld as competent under s. 59.

key_quotes.text: "The Municipalitys power to tax arises only under s. 59. Under that section, it has been given the power of impose a tax after following the procedure prescribed but subject always to the general or special orders of the Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on scope of s. 59.

key_quotes.text: "Hence, in our view, impose in s. 59 means the actual levy of the tax after authority to levy it has been acquired by rules duly made and sanctioned, and it is such imposition that is made subject to the general or special orders of the Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In my judgment the imposition of a tax is a continuing power in the sense that so long as it is in force, it points to the existence of and derives vitality from the power of the authority to impose it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Ayyangar J. on continuing nature of imposition power.
